document.title: South Carolina College- and Career-Ready Standards for Mathematics

042369EA0A5A418AA4F12AF2360A3C8C.description:
Apply 2 × 2 matrices as transformations of the plane, and interpret the absolute value of the
determinant in terms of area.

A020FBC931AC4E59BB923F906CB6A721.description:
Multiply a vector by a matrix of appropriate dimension to produce another vector. Work with
matrices as transformations of vectors.

9BD0370BD3334B8FBDD8545188E41416.description:
Understand that the zero and identity matrices play a role in matrix addition and multiplication
similar to the role of 0 and 1 in the real numbers. The determinant of a square matrix is nonzero
if and only if the matrix has a multiplicative inverse.

34492EEB65F4480DB2235FF632A0CC75.description:
Understand that, unlike multiplication of numbers, matrix multiplication for square matrices is
not a commutative operation, but still satisfies the associative and distributive properties.

9F13BD9D4774448E878AC5ED07180952.description:
Perform operations with matrices of appropriate dimensions including addition, subtraction, and
scalar multiplication.

C1D118D8DEF54343B96D3EC0675B388B.description: Use matrices to represent and manipulate data.

44C7AB69BCE14BC996207B1BCACB023F.description:
Multiply a vector by a scalar, representing the multiplication graphically and computing the
magnitude of the scalar multiple

9A5CC5F9099C43D6844D559B39D1810C.description:
Given the magnitude and direction of two vectors, determine the magnitude of their
sum and of their difference.

09F973A8A17048C19E116C729E1B018C.description: Add and subtract vectors using components of the vectors and graphically

15640A06AB5E46CDA3B3465C4F42795B.description:
Represent and model with vector quantities. Solve problems involving velocity and other
quantities that can be represented by vectors.

02D42C5AC4874E4A9DD5055B1FC7B55A.description:
Represent and model with vector quantities. Use the coordinates of an initial point and of a
terminal point to find the components of a vector.

AE244ED3E1DE40B8959977350A058395.description:
Recognize vector quantities as having both magnitude and direction. Represent vector quantities
by directed line segments, and use appropriate symbols for vectors and their magnitudes.

12DF479850B9484FB835823231735054.description:
Know the Fundamental Theorem of Algebra and explain why complex roots of polynomials with
real coefficients must occur in conjugate pairs.

B57BEDE210484FF49D38A2E774301A09.description:
Extend polynomial identities to the complex numbers and use DeMoivre’s Theorem to calculate
a power of a complex number.

1F8E4A2B3C164295964346E00C66A7F6.description: Solve quadratic equations in one variable that have complex solutions.

387C37C20B394EA99787A4CDA329B4BE.description:
Determine the modulus of a complex number by multiplying by its conjugate and determine the
distance between two complex numbers by calculating the modulus of their difference.

7250656E8FEC43278FC779B39FFA290C.description:
Represent addition, subtraction, multiplication, and conjugation of complex numbers
geometrically on the complex plane; use properties of this representation for computation.

B5B33A209B82425196F848E9A749CD45.description:
Graph complex numbers on the complex plane in rectangular and polar form and explain why
the rectangular and polar forms of a given complex number represent the same number.

685B5272065C4BDA9F17F0CE5BB56F80.description:
Find the conjugate of a complex number in rectangular and polar forms and use conjugates to
find moduli and quotients of complex numbers.

F853BF52A2F54A5DB7B5B0AF26C67BD7.description:
Use the relation 𝑖
2 = −1 and the commutative, associative, and distributive properties to add,
subtract, and multiply complex numbers.

3EC993AE8C974CF7B6A896818C36AADA.description:
Know there is a complex number 𝑖 such that 𝑖
2 = −1, and every complex number has the form
𝑎 + 𝑏𝑖 with 𝑎 and 𝑏 real.

14384067253E4588A6ED7E91748DC72E.description:
Explain why the sum or product of rational numbers is rational; that the sum of a rational number
and an irrational number is irrational; and that the product of a nonzero rational number and an
irrational number is irrational.

ABB8E9D971B844578F566C360AF4DD28.description:
Use the definition of the meaning of rational exponents to translate between rational exponent
and radical forms.

19E99A840E1D4C85BF40C2A6A1BB107E.description: Rewrite expressions involving simple radicals and rational exponents in different forms

F69C410E876D444CAA86B57C47619804.description:
Choose a level of accuracy appropriate to limitations on measurement when reporting quantities
in context

CEE4D4F42C4F40AA923006DE3BC29974.description: Label and define appropriate quantities in descriptive modeling contexts.

6A7A2165277F4839BAE812612EB67E21.description:
Use units of measurement to guide the solution of multi-step tasks. Choose and interpret
appropriate labels, units, and scales when constructing graphs and other data displays.

DCB3AE2597AB493D992136BB2933B265.description:
Use the Law of Sines and the Law of Cosines to solve for unknown measures of sides and angles
of triangles that arise in mathematical and real-world problems.

C9E248A344034995953C6F53F7E27FB0.description: Prove the Laws of Sines and Cosines and use them to solve problems.

6E6B06EAED584F369680327B731D6127.description:
Derive the formula 𝐴 =
1
2
𝑎𝑏 sin 𝐶 for the area of a triangle by drawing an auxiliary line from a
vertex perpendicular to the opposite side.

F77F1CE8CC45428586CF1E3DE453578F.description:
Solve right triangles in applied problems using trigonometric ratios and the Pythagorean
Theorem.

E54EC65734AA4D1493F13EAA51657AD4.description: Explain and use the relationship between the sine and cosine of complementary angles.

B61B0EA05CBF4D568C467BD163F02B49.description:
Understand how the properties of similar right triangles allow the trigonometric ratios to be
defined and determine the sine, cosine, and tangent of an acute angle in a right triangle.

9C036D4EF2454F42B8BED6279C906222.description:
Use congruence and similarity criteria for triangles to solve problems and to prove relationships
in geometric figures.

750F23F13A5B4B82A8229FCFB5011F6E.description:
The square of the hypotenuse of a right triangle is equal to the sum of squares of the
other two sides.

B58B8998C5D04DAF8F7AE061D817FB39.description:
If a line divides two sides of a triangle proportionally, then it is parallel to the third
side.

6CA0BDFEDC3B4B828F3B6BBDE6851562.description:
A line drawn parallel to one side of a triangle divides the other two sides into parts of
equal proportion.

49D3578B0C6C415AAF3269DD0A7C7328.description:
Prove, and apply in mathematical and real-world contexts, theorems involving similarity about
triangles, including the following:

93115322F34D4B01A519490090DB5EF3.description:
Prove that two triangles are similar using the Angle-Angle criterion and apply the proportionality
of corresponding sides to solve problems and justify results.

DB05A1E4918B4F3FAD4229AEFF8BCF47.description:
Use the definition of similarity to decide if figures are similar and justify decision. Demonstrate
that two figures are similar by identifying a combination of translations, rotations, reflections,
and dilations in various representations that move one figure onto the other.

145DB3767A0046429631607DEE589349.description:
Understand a dilation takes a line not passing through the center of the dilation to a parallel line,
and leaves a line passing through the center unchanged. Verify experimentally the properties of
dilations given by a center and a scale factor. Understand the dilation of a line segment is longer
or shorter in the ratio given by the scale factor.

AF3EDF8DB009490D93B87D021FC387AE.description:
Use geometry concepts and methods to model real-world situations and solve problems using a
model.

23E1A926622740A68E3B1F543F25FB54.description: Use geometric shapes, their measures, and their properties to describe real-world objects.

523AD736AE8E47A7885EEA6B29EBC2AF.description:
Use the distance and midpoint formulas to determine distance and midpoint in a coordinate
plane, as well as areas of triangles and rectangles, when given coordinates.

57AE305F571847F3BCDEAC3C143BC51B.description:
Given two points, find the point on the line segment between the two points that divides the
segment into a given ratio.

36A44EFC5F9A4854A9C6A9B84C0E34E6.description:
Analyze slopes of lines to determine whether lines are parallel, perpendicular, or neither. Write
the equation of a line passing through a given point that is parallel or perpendicular to a given
line. Solve geometric and real-world problems involving lines and slope.

4CF60071E28146E9BC8CBC30EBB2C8EF.description: Use coordinates to prove simple geometric theorems algebraically.

4E9E5AF61D8A443EA6655B682F472271.description:
Use the geometric definition of an ellipse and of a hyperbola to derive the equation of each given
the foci and points whose sum or difference of distance from the foci are constant.

29983C6218BD4D09B5CB223455514552.description: Use the geometric definition of a parabola to derive its equation given the focus and directrix.

9D68F9ADF49C4AD4BDF12CE943E1ECCC.description:
Understand that the standard equation of a circle is derived from the definition of a circle and the
distance formula.

80EA10C60BBA4A72888BE5774C4911F1.description:
Describe the shapes of two-dimensional cross-sections of three-dimensional objects and use
those cross-sections to solve mathematical and real-world problems.

89F7EE709CF14F97BB2EE0FE865FEF37.description:
Apply surface area and volume formulas for prisms, cylinders, pyramids, cones, and spheres to
solve problems and justify results. Include problems that involve algebraic expressions,
composite figures, geometric probability, and real-world applications.

C5BE1ACF1ABB43ECB8C4718A53B72EF1.description:
Explain the derivation of the formulas for the volume of a sphere and other solid figures using
Cavalieri’s principle.

D1D6A007694D410EA0DA52F2244BDAED.description:
Explain the derivations of the formulas for the circumference of a circle, area of a circle, and
volume of a cylinder, pyramid, and cone. Apply these formulas to solve mathematical and real-world problems.

A02D2F2151E74B2B9EB745F47425A0D1.description:
Construct geometric figures using a variety of tools, including a compass, a straightedge,
dynamic geometry software, and paper folding, and use these constructions to make conjectures
about geometric relationships.

243CEB5E031C4D9C8548D39DDB529EE7.description: a parallelograms is a rhombus if and only if the diagonals are perpendicular

FFD06DA9AE7142BE89459506D0992979.description: rectangles are parallelograms with congruent diagonals

600EB0EB144B435AB92F3AD992499951.description: diagonals of a parallelogram bisect each other

369F02746BB241928BB53A7CD71E298A.description: opposite angles of a parallelogram are congruent

A520F8D3809A427D9F7B7BB50E54E2BE.description: opposite sides of a parallelogram are congruent

41D834D11DE0414A8D37352F2F929F86.description:
Prove, and apply in mathematical and real-world contexts, theorems about parallelograms,
including the following:

E749D19AED1C49C6979002929F9C4A3B.description: the medians of a triangle meet at a point

C0C061E9BE68441F9BAB7C52BA79FF6A.description:
the segment joining midpoints of two sides of a triangle is parallel to the third side and
half the length

31AE986E993C466292D479B933909559.description: base angles of isosceles triangles are congruent

E37985A507D64481B4B61937035D05B7.description: measures of interior angles of a triangle sum to 180°

9B129A3A59DB4AD783963D7DC8C78140.description:
Prove, and apply in mathematical and real-world contexts, theorems about the relationships
within and among triangles, including the following:

7C40542E98174301B737258079B32FDB.description: perpendicular lines form four right angles

F1AB7303EE004B7C97BA58CB2392C84A.description:
any point on a perpendicular bisector of a line segment is equidistant from the
endpoints of the segment

22C056F9C9E44C72894873653640CB6F.description:
when a transversal crosses parallel lines, alternate interior angles are congruent,
alternate exterior angles are congruent, and consecutive interior angles are
supplementary

541DE9243FEC4F59B27C9C51775E8814.description:
Prove, and apply in mathematical and real-world contexts, theorems about lines and angles,
including the following:

9DC31B9405CC49368E4D5484FCF0893F.description: Prove two triangles are congruent by applying the Side-Angle-Side, Angle-Side-Angle, AngleAngle-Side, and Hypotenuse-Leg congruence conditions.

2E5FA467299A455C8320D05D710B6346.description:
Demonstrate that triangles and quadrilaterals are congruent by identifying a combination of
translations, rotations, and reflections in various representations that move one figure onto the
other

199095BE6ECF42268DEC4ABA213390D2.description:
Predict and describe the results of transformations on a given figure using geometric terminology
from the definitions of the transformations, and describe a sequence of transformations that maps
a figure onto its image.

2FBF472A53CC4813B117BAE6B425BEB6.description:
Develop definitions of rotations, reflections, and translations in terms of angles, circles,
perpendicular lines, parallel lines, and line segments.

C7D669E7E5094CB48A43FD85398EBDDC.description:
Describe rotations and reflections that carry a regular polygon onto itself and identify types of
symmetry of polygons, including line, point, rotational, and self-congruence, and use symmetry
to analyze mathematical situations

F6F15172CB664C2E8CCDCB0BAA74DA4A.description:
Represent translations, reflections, rotations, and dilations of objects in the plane by using paper
folding, sketches, coordinates, function notation, and dynamic geometry software, and use
various representations to help understand the effects of simple transformations and their
compositions.

0C2289ECE9F64B4685199B41BE9C19F5.description:
Define angle, perpendicular line, parallel line, line segment, ray, circle, and skew in terms of the
undefined notions of point, line, and plane. Use geometric figures to represent and describe real-world objects.

F5AC6F1130CD48248BF0403C9168F3B8.description:
Derive the formulas for the length of an arc and the area of a sector in a circle and apply these
formulas to solve mathematical and real-world problems.

411C43A153594911AA7621FFC99857BC.description:
Construct a tangent line to a circle through a point on the circle, and construct a tangent line from
a point outside a given circle to the circle; justify the process used for each construction.

DF3228938CFF417C8ADF5186AD883DCF.description:
Construct the inscribed and circumscribed circles of a triangle using a variety of tools, including
a compass, a straightedge, and dynamic geometry software, and prove properties of angles for a
quadrilateral inscribed in a circle.

346A9D7CFD07490D81EEED8A4CE84E99.description:
Identify and describe relationships among inscribed angles, radii, and chords; among inscribed
angles, central angles, and circumscribed angles; and between radii and tangents to circles. Use
those relationships to solve mathematical and real-world problems.

22B0DAB6C22A42F1B01120CBD168E16E.description: Prove that all circles are similar.
